data.text: @Brandon_Beaber @themsguide That's why those should not b mandated for highschool & college students. Kids should not b taking risks in order to get education.
@Brandon_Beaber Yes, they should b afraid. Preventive treatment should not have risk where there s no risk.

@Brandon_Beaber It is about contextualising the risks as well as stating that there are potential risks. Without context they can be perceived as more likely than they are. 

Expressed as per 10k what is the incidence vaccine related peri/myo carditis in this group?

@Brandon_Beaber And the study (meta-analysis) is talking about the difference between perceived vs actual. It is not dismissing the fact that there can be side effects nor the seriousness /severity of them. 

The fact remains that the nocebo effect is significant.

@anne_lh3 The infection fatality rate in this age group is enormously greater than the risk of side effects (granted, it is different for people who already had covid-19, and these studies are in unvaccinated people prior to omicron) https://t.co/DrSPntkMO6
@JHowardBrainMD From VAERS.  Here is the link: https://t.co/CUC7GpJjX6

@themsguide Interesting.  This may be true for mild transient side effects, but there are certainly legitimate significant side effects from Covid-19 vaccines (though rare).  The biggest concern is myocarditis/pericarditis after the 2nd dose of mRNA vaccines in young men age 16-24.

@Brandon_Beaber Men of that age have near zero chance of any serious issues from covid. Oh, and they’re all either still going to get covid or have already had it. So the booster just adds to their low odds of any issues. Doesn’t take a genius, or a dr., to figure out the stupidity of a booster
